author: mahmoodn
body:
Hi
It seems that WSMan is not available in the Linux environment. For example, the following command
```
Set-Item WSMan:\localhost\Client\TrustedHosts -Value "10.1.1.50" -force
```
Works on windows client. However, on Ubuntu 20.04 with powershell 7.1, I get this error

```
PS /home/mahmood> Set-Item WSMan:\localhost\Client\TrustedHosts -Value "10.1.1.50" -force
Set-Item: Cannot find drive. A drive with the name 'WSMan' does not exist.
```
Is there any alternative for that? Or WSMan is totally incompatible with Linux?

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: There’s no WSMan provider on Linux as most of the functionality here does not translate on non-Windows hosts. There’s no TrustedHosts or Auth settings for the client or server to set.

comments.author: mahmoodn
jborean93
comments.body: You don’t need to at all on Linux. Effectively all hosts are trusted hosts.

comments.author: mahmoodn
comments.body:
> ```
> Set-Item WSMan:\localhost\Client\TrustedHosts -Value $RemoteMachine -force
> $RemoteUsername = 'user'
> $RemotePassword = ' '
> $pass = ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText $RemotePassword -Force
> $Cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList $RemoteUsername,$pass
> 
> Invoke-Command -ComputerName $RemoteMachine -Credential $Cred -ScriptBlock { 
>                    & {
>                    diskpart /s c:\diskman.txt
>                    } } 
> ```
If I remove that `Set-Item` command, I get this error
```
Line |
  75 |  Invoke-Command -ComputerName $RemoteMachine -Credential $Cred -Script …
     |  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | This parameter set requires WSMan, and no supported WSMan client library was found. WSMan
     | is either not installed or unavailable for this system.
```

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: There is no WSMan drive on Linux, there’s nothing you need to do to trust a host unlike on Windows. If you are using PSWSMan you need to install the library with `Install-WSMan` as root and then restart powershell.
